Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Understanding the Evolution and Nature of Shocks and Sheets in Space Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Principal Investigator (PI) intends to investigate the nature of shocks and their corresponding plasma sheets using new in situ spacecraft observations, analytic theory, and numerical modeling. Her research will focus on how shocks form close to the Sun, evolve, and then propagate through the solar wind to Earth and beyond. The PI's goals specifically involve studying how shocks form and evolve in the heliosphere, how plasma flows in sheets behave, which mechanism(s) accelerate solar energetic particles (SEPs), identifying the probable sources of shocks, how shocks propagate in the structured solar wind, what causes the observed variability in heliospheric particle composition, and what determines the structure of solar, coronal, and heliospheric magnetic fields.

Shocks are present everywhere in the solar system, from close to the Sun to the outer edges of the solar system. They are believed to accelerate particles to extremely high energies (as in SEPs), which are a major space weather hazard and pose serious concerns for the design and operation of both manned and unmanned space missions. The PI's study of the nature of shocks and how they evolve as they propagate from the Sun to the Earth will provide improved space weather forecasting capability. The PI will also develop an innovative workshop program for mentoring young women in space science, which promises to encourage greater involvement of this underrepresented group.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goals of this project were to develop the building blocks for understanding the nature of shocks and their corresponding plasma sheets: how they form close to the Sun, evolve, propagate to Earth and beyond.  Shocks are present everywhere in the solar system, from close to the Sun to the outer edges of the solar system. They are believed to accelerate particles to extremely high energies (such as solar energetic particles SEPs) that are a major hazard for space weather, posing a serious concern for the design and operation of both manned and unmanned space missions. While it is generally accepted that the largest energetic particle events are created by coronal mass ejection (CME)-driven shocks in interplanetary space, several crucial aspects are not well-understood, and are an area of active research. Although our understanding of (collisionless) shocks has been advanced in recent years, we still lack a comprehensive study on how the evolution of shocks (and their characteristics) is affected by the environment in which they propagate. In particular, it is expected that the efficiency of the acceleration of particles will depend on the shock’s geometry and strength, which will be a function of the shock’s initial structure and the solar wind environment into which it propagates. From the in-situ observations of our outermost shock, the termination shock, by Voyager 1 and 2, several shock paradigms have had to be revisited. We lack a detailed understanding of the important physical processes and characteristics of the shock evolution from Sun to Earth and beyond. It is clear that in order to arrive at a fundamental physics-based picture, we need to take a cross-disciplinary approach that combines space physics, plasma physics and space weather. Our previous results show that the structure and geometry of shocks and sheets are complex and affected by the structured solar wind and magnetic field embedded in it. We propose to build on our previous knowledge based on the new in-situ observation and focus on studying the nature of shocks and sheets, including interplanetary shocks near Earth and beyond (e.g., the termination shock), using analytic theory and numerical modeling. This approach was done in close relation with existing data. The long-term goals are to understand the nature of shocks and sheets, including: (1) how shocks form and evolve in the heliosphere, (2) how the flows in the sheets behave, (3) what mechanism(s) accelerate SEPs, (4) what the probable sources of shocks are, (5) how shocks propagate in the structured solar wind, in the space near Earth (and Mars), (6) what causes the observed variability in particle composition, and (7) what determines the structure of solar, coronal, and heliospheric magnetic field. A deeper understanding of the nature of shocks and how they evolve from Sun to Earth will enable us to develop a better predictive capability for space weather and all that entails.

 

  • As part of the project we also run a series of successful summer schools for graduate and upper undergraduate students entitled “Plasma Physics Processes in Space Physics: Theory, Data and Computational Analysis.” Each summer school program will include interrelated lectures from top level experts in plasma physics, with a strong focus on how theoretical concepts manifest in observational spacecraft data and computational work. A link for the summer school is 

The 2012 Summer School: http://www.bu.edu/csp/edoutreach/plasma-summer-school-2012/

 

The 2014 Summer School: http://people.bu.edu/mopher/PlasmaSummerSchool2014/Welcome.html

 

The summer school were a big success involving leading plasma and space physics teaching a broad range of topics. http://people.bu.edu/mopher/PlasmaSummerSchool/Schedule.html

 

Its also involved hands on Laboratories. In the last day of both schools we had a panel on women in science with leaders in the field.

 

We developed a state of the art solar wind model driven by damping of surface alfven profile. Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs) are one of the main drivers of Space Weather and pinning down their trajectory is crucial.  We investigated the structures formed in sheath driven by CMEs. Another major challenge is the accurate prediction of arrival of Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs) near Earth at 1AU. Most works use sophisticated numerical modeling that are only able to model 1 event at a time. We developed a much quicker model taking into account the magnetic forces acting on the CME in the lower corona, that is able to run 1000 of cases. Because of its speed we are able to scan the phase space of all the possible masses, sizes and speeds of CMEs. We developed a model that describe the rotation and deflection of CMEs. We also explored how magnetic reconnection a process where magnetic field of opposite polarities can annihilate can accelerate particles in the outer sheath of the solar wind; the heliosheath. We explored how magnetic reconnection can be playing a role in the last boundary that separates us from the rest of the galaxy the heliopause.
